title: Who were the victims of The Jinx’s accused killer Robert Durst?
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Sky Crime’s gripping documentary The Jinx explores the alleged crimes of the accused murderer Robert Durst.

The series delved deep into the accusations against the New York real estate heir, who was suspected of having murdered three people – his first wife Kathleen McCormack Durst, his long-time friend Susan Berman, and his neighbour Morris Black.

Although he was later acquitted for Morris’ death, Durst allegedly confessed to ‘killing them all’ in the shocking final scene of the true-crime programme, when he took a toilet break and didn’t realise his microphone was still recording.

Advertisement

Let’s take a look into the lives of his victims.

Kathleen ‘Kathie’ McCormack

Kathleen McCormack was Durst’s first wife and she mysteriously vanished in New York in 1982.

She was a student in her fourth and final year at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in The Bronx and was only a few months short of earning her degree.

Durst’s wife Kathleen McCormack’s body has never been recovered (Picture: HBO)

Shortly before her disappearance, Kathleen had been treated at a Bronx hospital for facial bruises three weeks before. She told a friend that Durst beat her but did not press charges over the incident.

On top of that, she had asked Durst for a $250,000 divorce settlement but he canceled his wife’s credit card and removed her name from their joint bank account and refused to pay her tuition fees.

At the same time Kathleen disappeared, Durst had been dating Prudence Farrow for three years and was living in a separate apartment.

Durst was married to Kathleen (Picture: HBO)

Kathleen was last seen by someone other than Durst on January 31, 1982, when she made a surprise appearance at a dinner party thrown by her friend Gilberte Najamy in Connecticut.

Gilberte noticed that Kathleen looked upset and was wearing red tracksuit bottoms, which he thought was odd because she usually dressed better.

Kathleen then left for South Salem, New York after receiving a call from her husband.

Although the couple argued and fought, Durst maintained that he put his wife on a train to New York City, had a drink with a neighbor, and spoke to his Kathleen by telephone later that evening.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘That’s what I told police,’ Durst later told documentary filmmakers of The Jinx.

‘I was hoping that would just make everything go away.’

After leaving Gilberte’s house the pair had planned to meet at a pub in Manhatten, but when Kathleen failed to show up he became concerned and repeatedly called the police.

Durst filed a missing persons report several days later and he initially offered $100,000 (£77,713) for his wife’s return, then reduced the reward to $15,000 (£11,657)

Less than one month after Kathleen went missing, he was seen throwing away her possessions, which he denied.

Kathleen’s body has never been found but was declared dead in 2017.

Susan Berman

Susan Berman was a longtime friend of Durst and was killed, execution-style in her home in California on 24 December 2000.

Before her death, she had provided Durst with an alibi after Kathleen’s disappearance and had also received $50,000 (£38,856) from him.

Durst and Susan were friends (Picture: HBO)

Durst is known to have been in Northern California days before Susan was killed, and to have flown from San Francisco to New York the night before her body was found.

He did confirm to the LAPD that he’d recently sent Susan $25,000 (£19,428) and faxed investigators a copy of her 1982 deposition regarding his missing wife, but he declined to be questioned further on Susan’s murder.

Advertisement

In a 2005 deposition, Durst said that Susan had called him shortly before her death to say the LAPD wanted to talk about his wife Kathleen’s disappearance.

Morris Black

Morris Black was Durst’s neighbour and was killed in Texas in 2001.

Durst was convicted of dismembering Morris and scattering his remains in Galveston Bay and he claimed he shot the victim in self-defense.

The property mogul was later acquitted of the murder in 2003, but he later served time in prison after pleading guilty to a number of charges including tampering with evidence.

Although the documentary The Jinx led to Robert’s arrest, his trial has been put back until January 2020 due to various factors including ‘serious surgery’.

The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst is available on Sky Crime.
